newsitem.title: FRANCE: France sees Poland in European Union by 2000.
newsitem.headline: France sees Poland in European Union by 2000.

text.p: French President Jacques Chirac will tell Polish leaders on a state visit to Warsaw this week that he sees Poland joining the European Union within a few years, his spokeswoman said on Monday.

An informed source said Chirac would set the goal of the former communist state joining the Union by the year 2000, with a transition period thereafter until its agriculture was fully integrated into the single market.

Spokeswoman Catherine Colonna told reporters: "Poland is indisputably a quality candidate, given the considerable work that has already been achieved by this country..One can aim for a horizon of a few years."

She declined to name a date but said the president would do so when he addresses a joint session of the Polish parliament on Thursday during his first visit to one of the new democracies of central and eastern Europe.

Colonna also said France saw Poland opening negotiations to join NATO by the end of next year, following a summit of the Atlantic Alliance, central European candidates and east European partners, including Russia and Ukraine, early next year.

On EU accession, she said much would depend on the conclusion of the current inter-governmental conference (IGC) on reforming EU institutions, which is supposed to be wrapped up by the end of June 1997, but which is moving very slowly.
The EU has agreed to open negotiations with nine eastern and southern candidate nations six months after the end of the IGC.

But officials in Brussels say even the most ardent supporters of rapid enlargement believe the most likely batch of new members -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic -- are unlikely to gain admission before 2002.

By advocating an earlier date, diplomats said Chirac would highlight a shift in policy from his predecessor, Francois Mitterrand, who alienated many east Europeans by declaring after the fall of communism that it would be "decades" before they joined the EU.
